docs.lead_paragraph: Drug company executives asked the White House today for a cease-fire in their war over drug prices and said unequivocally that they wanted to work with President Clinton and Congress to establish Medicare coverage of prescription drugs this year. In the past, the industry had said it could accept Medicare coverage of prescription drugs only as part of a comprehensive plan to redesign the entire Medicare program. Companies feared that government-subsidized coverage of drugs would lead to government efforts to set drug prices, an idea the industry firmly opposes.

headline.main: DRUG MAKERS DROP THEIR OPPOSITION TO MEDICARE PLAN

docs.abstract: Drug company executives say they want to work with Pres Clinton and Congress to establish Medicare coverage of prescription drugs this year; industry's position in past was that it would accept Medicare coverage of prescription drugs only as part of comprehensive plan to redesign entire Medicare program; companies feared that government-subsidized coverage of drugs would lead to government efforts to set drug prices; spokesmen for industry's trade group, Pharmaceutical Research and Manufacturers of America, acknowledge their concern that Pres Clinton would attack their industry in his upcoming State of the Union Message; some Democrats see overture by drug executives as ploy to take heat off industry; others see it as catalyst for negotiations; drug executives' conciliatory statements suggest that they see Medicare drug coverage as inevitable and want to make best deal possible (M)
docs.snippet: Drug company executives asked the White House today for a cease-fire in their war over drug prices and said unequivocally that they wanted to work with President Clinton and Congress to establish Medicare coverage of prescription drugs this year.   ...

docs.lead_paragraph: Over the years, the Iowa caucuses have made some presidential candidates (like Jimmy Carter in 1976) and unmade others (like Steve Forbes in 1996). But this time, they have seemed like a warm-up bout compared with the ballyhooed main event in New Hampshire. That may be changing. With only 10 days left until Jan. 24, when tens of thousands of Iowans will assemble in living rooms, clubs and school halls to declare their preferences, two well-funded, well-organized underdogs, Bill Bradley and Mr. Forbes, have accelerated their efforts. If not to defeat their respective rivals, Al Gore and George W. Bush, they hope to come close enough to get a lift as they move to New Hampshire, whose critical primary takes place only eight days later on Feb. 1.

headline.main: For Front-Runners and Underdogs Alike, Iowa Caucuses Could Be Crucial

docs.abstract: Iowa caucuses will be held on Jan 24, and Vice Pres Al Gore on Democratic side and Gov George W Bush on Republican side are expected winners; two well-funded, well-organized underdogs, Bill Bradley and Steve Forbes, are accelerating their efforts in Iowa, hoping, if not to defeat their respective rivals, to come close enough to get lift as they move to New Hampshire, whose critical primary takes place only eight days later, on Feb 1; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Over the years, the Iowa caucuses have made some presidential candidates (like Jimmy Carter in 1976) and unmade others (like Steve Forbes in 1996). But this time, they have seemed like a warm-up bout compared with the ballyhooed main event in New...

docs.lead_paragraph: The House majority leader, Representative Dick Armey of Texas, predicted today that Congress would pass a patients' bill of rights this spring and send it to President Clinton by Easter, April 23. But just how far those protections go, specifically on whether patients can sue health maintenance organizations, will no doubt be contentious as Democrats and Republicans seek the political high ground on a hot campaign issue.

headline.main: A Bill Protecting Patients' Rights Will Pass, House Republican Says

docs.abstract: House majority leader, Rep Dick Armey, predicts that Congress will pass patients' bill of rights this spring and send it to Pres Clinton by April 23; strong patients' bill of rights is top priority for Democrats on Capitol Hill, and Republicans are expected to try to defuse election-year issues by acting on them early, if at all, and passing more modest versions that are coupled with more traditional Republican elements; matter of whether patients can sue health maintenance organizations is expected to be contentious issue (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: The idea of computers being able to detect emotions boggles the mind. Once computer technology monitors human emotions, and that information becomes consciously or unconsciously available through Internet cookies, the door will be open for marketing opportunities, opinion polls, security forces and ultimately the government.
docs.abstract: Robert D Egby letter on Jan 6 article discusses implications of computers that are able to detect emotions

docs.lead_paragraph: A hastily prepared immigration law is causing enormous delays on the borders of the Czech Republic, one of Europe's most popular tourist destinations. To the embarrassment of customs officials, many foreigners trying to enter since Jan. 1 have waited up to eight hours at the border. Some have been asked to produce certain documents and fill out forms available only in Czech. Badly briefed, the guards did not know what to require and have faulted the legislators for passing the law at the last minute and requiring instant enforcement.

headline.main: Hastily Passed Law Delays Travelers at Czech Border Posts

docs.abstract: Hastily prepared immigration law in Czech Republic causes enormous delays on country's borders; border guards, badly briefed, do not know what to require; many foreigners trying to enter country wait up to eight hours at border; measure is part of effort to gain Czech Republic's entry into European Union; illegal immigrants trying to go to Germany often pass through Czech Republic (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: It would be hard to overestimate the capacity of New York State's lawmakers for fighting, especially over money. This is the gang, after all, that in the last six years has produced the five latest budgets in state history, including the two latest by any state since the Depression. But today, as Gov. George E. Pataki proposed his $76.8 billion budget for the fiscal year that starts April 1, even some of the Capitol's battle-scarred cynics said this year should be different. There will, as always, be a fight over education spending, but other traditional areas of conflict have been resolved in advance, and the governor, continuing to move away from the austerity that marked his first years in office, is offering a healthy enough spending increase -- more than 5 percent over all -- to make most of the Legislature happy.
docs.abstract: News analysis contends that while it would be hard to overestimate capacity of New York State's lawmakers for fighting, especially over money, they should be hard-pressed to find it difficult not to be able to reach agreement on Gov Pataki's proposed $76.8 billion state budget (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Saying New Jersey must make high technology ''the undisputed engine'' of its economic growth, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman proposed $100 million in new spending today to help researchers convert their scientific advances into thriving businesses, and to help train what she called ''the high-tech work force of tomorrow.'' In her sixth annual address to the Legislature, Mrs. Whitman, who in past years has used the occasion to tackle difficult problems like high auto insurance rates and rising property taxes, instead outlined a modest agenda for her remaining two years in office, with the state's economy, education, the environment, and the elderly all sharing her attention.

headline.main: Whitman Focuses on Aiding High Technology Initiatives

docs.abstract: New Jersey Gov Christine Todd Whitman, in State of State Message, proposes $100 million in new spending to help researchers convert their scientific advances into thriving businesses; also proposes various smaller plans to help elderly, bolster education system and make limited improvements in state's antipollution efforts (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: As she begins her final two years in office, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman appears to be quite comfortable that her legacy is secure. In delivering her State of the State address today -- the last before she enters the lame-duck year of her final term in office -- the governor laid out a modest array of economic and quality-of-life proposals: $100 million in state spending to spur high-technology business growth, plus a variety of smaller plans to help the elderly, bolster the education system and make limited improvements in New Jersey's antipollution efforts.
docs.abstract: News analysis contends that as she begins her final two years in office, New Jersey Gov Christine Todd Whitman appears to be quite comfortable that her legacy is secure; says that in delivering her State of the State address, she laid out modest array of economic and quality of life proposals: $110 million in state spending to spur high technology growth plus variety of smaller plans to help elderly, bolster education system and make limited improvements in state's antipollution efforts (M)
